trustfund:
TF021432-UN SPECIAL INITIATIVE FOR AFRICA,TF028942-COLLABORATION WITH IRELAND AID
            REGARDING EDUCATION IN AFRICA,TF036639-MALAWI - SECONDARY EDUCATION PROJECT,TF040492-MALAWI:  SECONDARY EDUCATION
            PROJECT - ARCHITECT/PHYSICAL INFRASTRUCTUR

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Secondary Education
            Project for Malawi were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: The need to ensure consistence of
            the PAD and DCA is important. A Clear Monitoring and
            Evaluation Framework including capacity building should be
            part of the project design. There should be mechanisms to
            enforce the functioning of Oversight Committees. Contracting
            work to private firms requires Government's capacity to
            effectively supervise the firms. A framework for quality
            assurance in relation to standards and specifications need
            to be clear and available at school and other levels to
            guide implementation and monitoring such as in relation to
            civil works and different supplies. Adequate guidelines for
            school mapping and site selection needs to be in place in
            all education projects. Involvement of stakeholders within
            communities where the schools have been constructed, was
            insufficient. Well established mechanisms for coordination
            should be in place in the government ministries to ensure
            adequate support is provided in project implementation.
            Issues of teacher supply, development and deployment need to
            be addressed more comprehensively to ensure adequate supply
            and effective deployment of qualified teachers for primary
            and secondary education.
